But he does not want to be the one to kill the deal – as this would lose him credibility once more. So he skilfully manoeuvres things so that the MDC will be forced to walk away from the table – leaving Mugabe where he fully intended to be all along – in the driving seat.

Despite the country collapsing around him and millions suffering from hunger and disease, there is method in Mugabe's madness. He is positioning himself for the next election – determined to reverse his humiliation at the hands of the electorate on March 29. He will never forgive Zimbabweans for rejecting him.

This is why he has insisted on retaining control of the power ministries, while giving MDC the service ministries. He needs the police and the army, home affairs and defence ministries, to seal off the rural areas, disrupt the MDC's activities and thrash and threaten its supporters. In addition, home affairs is responsible for the conduct of elections. He needs local government to retain control of the chiefs and keep them on side. He needs information to maintain his stranglehold on the media, keeping people in the dark – as is the wont of every dictator. Access to information for millions through the publication of the mass-circulation independent weekly, the Zimbabwean, is what cost him the March election – according to his election agent, Emmerson Mnangagwa.

And he needs foreign affairs to continue his world-wide campaign of hate-speech and disinformation against the west, and to continue to wag his tail for the Russians and the Chinese.

His henchmen, the military chiefs, have a particularly vested interest in keeping control over the police – most, if not all, of them could and certainly would be arrested by an MDC-controlled police force on a wide range of charges, from crimes against humanity to theft and corruption.

Mugabe wants the MDC, now united as Arthur Mutambara has been forced by his party to abandon his flirtation with Zanu-PF, to walk away from the deal. That's why he doesn't want Thabo Mbeki, the lame-duck turned dead-duck president/mediator, to come and fix it.

The governments of Europe today embarked on their biggest financial gamble since the launch of the euro single currency by pledging to buy tottering banks, underwrite their lending and flood the markets with liquidity in a package that could cost up to €2trillion (£1.5trillion) across the EU.

In a closely coordinated rash of announcements, Germany, France, Austria and Spain unveiled packages worth hundreds of billions of euros aimed at shoring up their banks and financial systems, while Italy, Sweden, Poland and Norway prepared parallel action.

The radical and risky moves followed an emergency summit of the 15 single currency countries in Paris on Sunday night which agreed a set of rules and instruments for the unprecedented state interventions modelled on the British government's triple-whammy strategy unveiled last week.

The scale, ambition and potential costs of the programmes suggested European leaders were determined to rise to the challenge of the financial crisis through concerted action, displaying a degree of leadership that put Washington, the global economic leader, in the shade.

"United Europe has pledged more than the US," said Nicolas Sarkozy, the French president and current chairman of the EU, as he announced a €360bn package for France.

The day began with Gordon Brown explaining his bail-out of British banks and calling for an overhaul of the global financial system. Then the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, announced a €500bn rescue plan for Germany, and Sarkozy made his announcement. The Austrian and Spanish governments revealed plans to each make €100bn available for bank buyouts, interbank lending and bank bond issuance guarantees.

Across the 15-country eurozone, the overall bill for the various national schemes could top a trillion euros. Factoring in Britain's package, estimated to cost £500bn as well as parallel plans in the parts of Scandinavia and central Europe outside the eurozone, the cost to the 27 countries of the EU could soar to €2trillion.

It appears that European leaders are betting their political careers on the attempt to calm and restore confidence in the financial markets. For the first time in weeks of panic and meltdown, there was an air of cautious optimism that Europe's response, after weeks of dithering and incohesive rhetoric, offered the best chance of stabilising a financial system careering out of control.

"European policymakers are now racing ahead of the US in their efforts to solve the crisis," said the Italian Unicredit bank, while the Bank of America said: "After a haphazard start, Europe is finally getting its act together. The size and nature of the national plans suggest that they could finally make a difference."

Announcing a "financial market stabilisation fund", Merkel indicated she was abandoning her aim of balancing Germany's budget by 2011. The German finance ministry put the scale of the German scheme at €500bn, with the bulk, as everywhere else, being earmarked to guarantee medium-term bank lending to try to jolt the banks out of their sclerosis and banish fear and suspicion. About €70bn, with the option to top that up by €10bn, could be used to recapitalise troubled financial institutions. A bill implementing the plan is to be rushed through the German parliament by Friday.

The German fund is the near-equivalent of its annual budget and comes just when the country is recovering from the mammoth costs of financing German unification over the past 15 years.

As decided on Sunday, the loan guarantees would run until the end of next year, in Germany as well as everywhere else in the eurozone.

A summit of the EU-27 on Wednesday in Brussels is expected to adopt Sunday's blueprint for the entire EU. Finance ministers are to take part in the summit which will be addressed by Jean-Claude Trichet, the head of the European Central Bank.

Unlike Brown and Sarkozy, who have been keen to launch the series of coordinated national rescue schemes, Merkel has been sceptical for the past week. Her rhetoric on the bail-outs is markedly different from the urgency being advocated by Brown and Sarkozy.

Austria announced a €100bn scheme, 85% of it to be used to underwrite bank lending if necessary. Spain offered an identical fund to guarantee bank bond issuance but said there was no need yet to make money available for banks' recapitalisation. Italy's central bank offered to buy bank debt to the tune of €40bn.

The banking sectors in Spain and France are believed to be the healthiest in Europe, requiring less intervention. Nonetheless, Sarkozy proposed legislation to be pushed through parliament this week allocating €360bn of which €40bn could be used to buy parts of ailing banks.

Hometown: Toronto, Canada.
The lineup: Vello Verder (guitar, vocals), Jon Hawkes (vocals, drums), Marc Delparte (bass, vocals).
The background: They formed less than a year ago, in February 2008, but already Les Gars, their name taken from the 1956 film Si Tous Les Gars Du Monde about a trawler in the North Atlantic stricken with botulism, are being highly touted, not just by actual gig-going punters but by bands - apparently, Killers, Kasabian and Editors are all big early supporters of the band. It's probably just as well that they're accruing a celebrity fanbase because the Canadian trio, who played a well-received set at last week's In The City, need the attention and, more pertinently, the money. They've just moved to London and are currently sleeping either on friends' floors or in their tour van. Not surprisingly, finding ways to live comfortably yet affordably is a major concern for them, and they clearly had work and wedge on their minds when they wrote the songs for the debut EP, which includes three-chord thrash-and-burn numbers about minimum-wage jobs, buying a house in a hostile economy and the boredom of the rat race.
If those sound like ingredients for the most basic, primal punk'n'roll band from 1976, that's because Les Gars could easily have propped up the bill at the Marquee on those nights when Chelsea, Eater and Slaughter & the Dogs were otherwise engaged. They've lived low-rent lives: mainman Verder has in his short life been a waiter, a tree surgeon, an office worker and a fine china salesman – meaning the china was fine, not that he was particularly good at selling it. What he is quite good at is penning tunes in the dead of night: he's a bit of an insomniac who keeps a pen, paper and dictionary by his mattress ready to jot down ideas as and when they come. Hence the blurry, slurry nature of his songs about girls, booze and modern life being a bit, well, rubbish. He doesn't think girls and booze are rubbish, though. No, he likes those a lot. And you'll like his music, if you happen to be into sloppy, ragged, rough'n'ready demo-quality garageland ramalama where the guitars, bass and drums all sound as though they are being played by drunken tramps wearing fingerless gloves and the singer sounds like he's been shouting all night. They were produced by Brian Karscig from Louis XIV and they make Towers of London sound like Shostakovich. It's nice to hear a band doing their bit, at this time of financial crisis, to keep budgets low. Their lack of sonic sophistication is positively parsimonious. There's something of the Strokes' energy in the track Haircut and a Gun (for which Verder got the idea after watching a documentary about the making of Platoon) – but the Strokes circa their dispirited and disengaged third album, not their debut - and shades of The Libertines in the slovenly She Sleeps. Nice Way to See Things borrows the riff from The Who's Who Are You but fails to take it anywhere while What I Want sounds like the Clash at their most weedy. Still, what a great cure for insomnia. The buzz: "Gritty weaned–on-whiskey vocals and eye-juddering bass lines that make the Vines' early stuff sound like it was made by a bunch of mummy's boys."
The truth: They're less old-fashioned than antediluvian.
Most likely to: Give you a headache.
Least likely to: Give you botulism.
What to buy: The La Physique EP is released on the band's own label on October 27. They play London's Club Zero on October 24.
File next to: The Vines, Babyshambles, The Clash, Manic Street Preachers.
Links: www.myspace.com/lesgars

The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, has sworn in two vice-presidents in a move that could further jeopardise crisis talks to rescue the power-sharing agreement in the country.

The move was announced before the arrival of the former South African president Thabo Mbeki in the capital, Harare, on a mission to salvage the accord he brokered last month.

"The two vice-presidents were sworn in this morning because their positions are not in dispute," a senior government official told Reuters.

Mugabe's unilateral allocation of important ministries to his Zanu-PF party at the weekend angered the opposition. The MDC said it doubted mediation efforts by Mbeki this week would get Zanu-PF to compromise.

Speaking at a rally of MDC supporters in Harare, Tsvangirai declared he was not prepared "to compromise for the sake of compromise".

Threatening to withdraw from the agreement, he said: "This struggle is about change. If we are not given the instruments of affecting change in your life, then this arrangement is stillborn."

Tsvangirai told the rally he would not be pressured by Mugabe into joining an administration dominated by Zanu-PF after the opposition Movement for Democratic Change won the last reputable elections in March.

"If they do it that way, we have no right to be part of such an arrangement," he said. "The people have suffered. But if it means suffering the more in order for them to get what is at stake, then so be it."

Under the deal, Mugabe retains the presidency and chairs the cabinet while Tsvangirai, as prime minister, will head a council of ministers supervising the cabinet.

Mugabe gazetted the appointment of new cabinet posts at the weekend, allocating his party control over the various security and intelligence forces as well as the justice portfolio and the information ministry, which controls Zimbabwe's highly partisan state newspapers and broadcasters.

The MDC described the move as a "giant act of madness which puts the whole deal into jeopardy", and as a ploy to pre-empt Mbeki's visit.

"The elite in Zanu-PF is not interested in addressing the current challenges in the country. Instead, they are obsessed with power retention at all costs," it said.

The MDC said it would agree to Zanu-PF having authority over the military, but that Tsvangirai must control home affairs, which oversees the police, and the justice ministry. That is important to Tsvangirai to ensure that Zanu-PF does not repeat its violent campaign at the next election.

Mugabe's move is a demonstration of his power to obstruct the political deal he described as "humiliating" after he was forced to sign it last month. But his position remains weak. There will be no foreign aid to rescue an economy collapsing under hyperinflation - officially put at 231 million per cent, but which in reality runs into the trillions - without Tsvangirai wielding real authority at the head of a genuine power-sharing government.

Mugabe only signed the political agreement with the opposition because his administration had no solutions to the economic crisis. While he can block implementation of the deal and keep control of the government, he will be left facing even deeper problems than when he was forced into the agreement.

Neither can Mugabe count on Mbeki to protect him. Although Mbeki remains the mediator, South Africa's new president, Kgalema Motlanthe, and those around him are hostile to Mugabe and there is a growing will inside the new government to confront the Zimbabwean leader.

The European Union condemned Mugabe's latest unilateral move. Britain's foreign secretary, David Miliband, said Europeans would "play no part in supporting a power grab by the Mugabe regime".

"It is important that there is an international united response that says that the results of the elections need to be respected and a power grab will not be respected," Miliband told reporters at EU talks in Luxembourg.

The EU has threatened to step up sanctions on Zimbabwe unless Mugabe sticks to the terms of the accord.

"If the agreement is not applied we shall resume our sanctions and reinforce them," said the French foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner. France currently holds the presidency of the EU.

Existing EU sanctions include visa bans and asset freezes on top Zimbabwean officials including Mugabe.

Yesterday, I got a call from a friend in Ljubljana, asking if my family and I were OK, and if we still had food and shelter. He sounded sure I had already lost my job, and offered to help. At first I did not understand what he was talking about: for the most part, life goes on as normal here in Iceland – but finally I realised he had been reading the British media.

The British prime minister has repeatedly said that Iceland, as a country, even as a nation, is going bankrupt, that our government has defaulted on its legal obligation, that we are virtually doomed – falling into an economic abyss. Neither is true. We have never denied our legal obligation regarding the Icesave accounts, and the people of Iceland are not going bust. Ask yourself: would you lend £100m, as Chancellor Darling has just announced he will, to a bankrupt?

Our currency might be in trouble and that hits us hard, our pay has been significantly devalued by rising costs, our stock exchange is still closed – but the foundations are still stable – no thanks to Gordon Brown and his menacing rhetoric of last week. And despite what is written in the London tabloids, we still go to work every day, receive our salaries, pay our bills and gather in the pub in the evenings. Today, Icelandic officials are in Moscow talking to the Russians who have offered a helping hand. The IMF is involved and many other measures are being taken – including, now, the Bank of England loan to Landsbanki.

Let's look at some facts, shall we? The high-flying, globetrotting business elite that came out of Iceland and started spreading borrowed money all over the UK and Europe has very little to do with the ordinary working public in Iceland. However, for some peculiar reason, the UK media thinks it is all our fault. It seems to me that you have fallen for a cruel and calculated PR stunt by Brown, whose only mission with his destructive attack on the Icelandic public was to save his miserable political life for another day. For that, the people of Iceland are paying severely.

Yes, of course, we are angry. We are angry towards these reckless business tycoons for gambling with our good name, the most precious asset a small nation can have. But ordinary Icelanders are no more responsible for the risk-seeking businessmen who happen to hold our passport than the people of north London are responsible for the destructive behaviour of the talented Amy Winehouse. And even though most of us still enjoy most things British, we are furious with the UK government. In fact, when Brown used anti-terrorist legislation to bully Iceland's largest private firm, Kaupthing bank, into the ground, he almost made us forgive our own government, which failed to act when the troubles started to rise on the horizon.

When the Republic of Iceland ran into the greatest troubles in its young life (it gained independence in 1944) and asked for help, none of our so-called friends stood up. The people of Iceland are paralysed by the lack of help and the destructive attack by the British PM. Iceland is an active participant in European cooperation and a founding member of Nato, but in the end, it seems Russia is Iceland's only friend. Brown's insult to Iceland will be remembered long after this £100m debt has been repaid.

The Independent Police Complaints Commission launched an investigation today after a Metropolitan police surveillance officer admitted he had altered evidence submitted to the Jean Charles de Menezes inquest.

The policeman, named only as Owen, told the hearing he had deleted one of his own computer notes that quoted the deputy assistant commissioner Cressida Dick - the officer in charge of operations when the Brazilian electrician was shot - as apparently concluding that De Menezes was not a security threat.

The note said: "CD - can run on to tube as not carrying anything" before adding that Dick's judgement apparently came about after she was "persuaded by U/I [unidentified] male amongst management".

Owen said he accessed his notes to remove the line on October 7, more than two weeks after the start of the hearing, because he "didn't see it as relevant".

"On reflection, I looked at that and thought I cannot actually say that," Owen told the inquest today, explaining his action. He told a Met solicitor about the changes the day after he submitted his evidence to the inquest, on October 8.

An IPCC spokesman said the organisation had "received a referral from the Metropolitan police service in relation to a matter arising from the inquest into the death of Jean Charles de Menezes".

He added: "This matter will be subject to an independent investigation and we are not in a position to comment further at this stage."

De Menezes, 27, was shot dead after boarding a train at Stockwell underground station in south London on July 22 2005 by anti-terrorism police who mistook him for a would-be suicide bomber.

The inquest, being held at the Oval cricket ground, near Stockwell, has heard that police feared De Menezes could be Hussein Osman, one of the attackers who launched failed suicide bomb attacks on London's public transport system the previous day.

When Dick gave evidence to the inquest last week she said she had had "no doubt" at the time that the right man was being targeted.

Asked today if he was aware of the seriousness of his actions in deleting the evidence, Owen said: "I have removed a line I believed was wrong and gave a totally false impression." He rejected the suggestion that senior officers had asked him to make the change, saying: "No. I am sure of that, sir."

He said he had checked through his notes and noticed a "few mistakes" and decided to make the amendments. Asked why, he said: "The detail changes do not materially affect the statement."

Owen said he was now not certain who had said "let him run" in reference to De Menezes. "All I can say was that one of the options was letting him run because he was not carrying anything and that there's a disagreement between management," he said.

"I believe it was the commander [Dick] but when I reflected I couldn't be sure or whether she was saying this is what we are going to do or this is one of the options. It was a woman's voice."

Minutes later, Owen said, Dick effectively directed the Brazilian's shooting by ordering a so-called "hard-stop". He said: "A hard stop is an aggressive stop. It's not an official term but it is an aggressive stop."

The inquest has heard evidence of confusion among surveillance teams detailed to follow De Menezes and ascertain whether he was, as suspected, Osman. The Brazilian lived in a south London block of flats linked by police to Osman.

Earlier today, another senior surveillance officer, named only as Pat, denied he had told superiors that De Menezes was a confirmed terrorism suspect.

Pat, the principal link at New Scotland Yard between surveillance officers on the ground and Dick, said the electrician was only "possibly identifiable with" Osman throughout the operation.

Guantánamo guards must furnish confessed al-Qaida kingpin Khalid Sheik Mohammed and his four alleged co-conspirators with enough battery power to use their prison camp laptops 12 hours a day but the 9/11 accused can't surf the internet, a military judge ruled.

Judge Ralph Kohlmann, a Marine colonel, issued the decision a week ago. It turned up Sunday on a defence department web site, which under the ruling the men will not be allowed to see live.

The five former CIA-held detainees are accused of the mass murder of 2,973 people on September 11 2001 in a complex conspiracy case that seeks military execution as the ultimate punishment.

They allegedly trained, financed and coordinated the September 11 hijackers, and are in pre-trial hearings at the US Navy base in southeast Cuba, where three of the five are now functioning as their own attorneys.

At issue of late has been what resources they get to prepare for the case inside a secret Guantánamo prison facility, called Camp 7, which is reserved for alleged terrorists who had earlier been interrogated somewhere overseas by the CIA.

"Reasonable access does not equate to a right or an entitlement to be placed on the same footing as a technologically state of the art law office," Kohlmann wrote in his three-page ruling.

Mohammed, his nephew Ammar al-Baluchi and Walid Bin Attash have sought through standby counsel filings at the military commission a long list of resources they say they need to mount their defence - including internet links to read news accounts and do live research on databases. They argued, in part, that their Pentagon appointed counsel and US civil liberties lawyers volunteering on their case are not always at the remote outpost as they prepare their defence.

Al-Baluchi, 31, who at his arraignment identified himself as Microsoft certified software engineer, in particular sought a DVD writer, PowerPoint software, printers, a scanner and a hotline to the Pentagon's defence counsel's office.

I was listening on Friday morning to a confused debate in the Conway Hall among atheists and secularists about what to do about Islam. Although it was billed as organised by the Council for Ex-Muslims, the crowd of about 300 was overwhelmingly white and middle-aged and looked to me more like long-standing members of the British Humanist Association.

On the platform were a couple of Iranian refugees who really have been threatened by a fascist theocracy; there was a Dutch defender of Ayaan Hirsi Ali, who thought she had done entirely the right thing in moving to an American rightwing thinktank; there was A C Grayling of this parish, who called her a friend but doubted her wisdom in going to America. From the sporadic clapping and counter-clapping, it was obvious that sentiment in the hall was deeply divided over whether home-grown fascism was a greater danger than religion. The only time these disagreements were overcome was when someone made a little speech about how no one minded religion as a private activity: it was only obnoxious when the religious tried to force their opinions on everyone else. The whole hall joined in applauding this sentiment, so obviously and unarguably right.

Perhaps it's just my limited tolerance for high-mindedness that gave me a sudden flash of insight that this doctrine was in fact obviously and unarguably wrong. I had fight back an urge turn it on its head – to stand up and say that no one minds secularism as a private belief: only when the secularists try to force their opinions on the rest of society do they become obnoxious.

Secularism is a doctrine about how society is best ordered. As such it cannot avoid imposing itself on those who disagree. To take two recent flashpoints – the secularists in the hall would all demand the abolition of faith schools, and an end to discrimination against gay people within religious bodies. Now, whatever you think of the merits of these proposals, they must involve interfering with people who disagree, and abrogating their freedom to act on their disagreements. Any attempt to privatise atheism in this respect, or to regard it as a forgiveable personal quirk which should have no bearing on public policy would be regarded by many atheists as an attempt at suppression, or even persecution. They would have a point. But the same point applies with equal force when made by believers.

Religions aren't just collections of beliefs about God, or gods. They are also beliefs about humanity, and the proper ends of being human. As such, they form part of a large groups of more or less worked out philosophies: secularism, utilitarianism, feminism, even Marxism and modern liberalism. None of these can, by their nature, be wholly private doctrines. If they are true at all, they are true of everyone, and certain consequences follow for the ordering of society.

To use feminism as an example: if someone were to say that feminism is all very well between consenting adults, but the law should not impose its conclusions on people who did not want to believe that equal work deserves equal pay, he would not only be told that he was wrong and disgusting, but that he had misunderstood the sort of claim that feminism makes of us. It is a claim about human nature: that women and men are not so different that treating them unequally is just. So it can't just be a private doctrine. Public consequences must follow.

Comparable, if often contradictory, beliefs about human rights and duties can be read off any religion worth arguing about as well as the broad philosophies I mentioned earlier. They can't all be right, of course; but some idea of human rights and duties is necessary for any society to function; and it can't by its nature be private.

We can, I think, reasonably demand in a liberal democracy that everyone obey the law once it has been made. But by the same token everyone is entitled to try to change the law through political means. This really does mean everyone: secularists and believers alike. Neither has the right to demand that the other keep their beliefs as a private eccentricity.

With banks being nationalised almost daily and the national debt now soaring well over the 40% which used to be Gordon Brown's target, what about the railways? Could it not be possible to slip them back into the public sector, something that many people would love to see happen?

There is undoubtedly a strong case to be made, since the railways may soon find themselves in financial difficulties. In recent years, passenger numbers have soared and the government has let a series of franchises on the basis that revenue will continue growing at 7-8% per year. This has partly been predicated on fares rising above the rate of inflation, and partly on an expectation that passenger numbers will continue growing.

So far there has been little sign of the impending recession, with patronage on the railways continue to increase, though at a slower rate. However, railways are very dependent on the general state of the economy and there is no doubt that passenger numbers will soon level off and start to go down. The above-inflation fares rises of 6% – with some rising by 11% – that will be imposed in January will probably be the turning point.

That will leave the train operators, and ultimately the government, in a real pickle. Many train operators are paying heavy premiums for the right to run services and if they plunge into the red, they will do an Oliver Twist on the government. Ministers have repeatedly said that they will not renegotiate franchises and that if big operators such as FirstGroup, Stagecoach or National Express throw in the towel on one franchise, it would have to hand back all its other ones as well. In a rational world, that would be the perfect opportunity for the Department for Transport to say, sorry guys, we are going to bring the franchises back in-house and effectively renationalise the railways.

That is to underestimate the absolute antipathy that New Labour has to nationalisation. The reluctance to step in over Northern Rock and the initial plan to take out only preference shares rather than normal stock which gives the government a say over the running of the banks in today's huge recapitalisation, demonstrates this. The recently sacked transport minister, Tom Harris, told me in an interview earlier this year that if New Labour had inherited British Rail, it would have privatised it. That was not, incidentally, the reason for his departure – being too rightwing has never been the cause of a New Labour minister's dismissal.

In fact, what New Labour refuses to let on is that the railways are effectively largely publicly-owned anyway. Network Rail, which owns the infrastructure, is a company without shareholders that is dependent on government backed debt (to the tune of £20bn), for its survival. It receives billions in annual grants direct from government and is, to all intents and purposes, a state-run enterprise.

Yet Peter Hain was quoted at the weekend as saying that there was no question of renationalising the railways because it would be too expensive. In fact, with Network Rail already in public hands, it would cost nothing to bring back the railways under public control if the train operators handed back the franchises either when they get into financial difficulties or when their terms expire.

Hain's dishonest argument, parroted for some time by successive transport ministers, suggests that British Rail will not emerge Phoenix-like from the ashes of the recession-hit railway system. The new transport secretary, Geoff Hoon, will undoubtedly toe the same line, but he will face a rocky time when the whole complex privatised edifice starts to fall apart as the expected growth of passengers on which it is based does not materialise.

Since he was detained by US immigration officials in August, four storms have torn through Jean Delva's homeland.

They wiped out roads and bridges, flooded fields and obliterated a meagre food supply. More than 850,000 people are displaced and 50,000 homes are damaged or destroyed. Hundreds died and UN officials say many more might if they don't get help.

Sending him back would be cruel, immigrant advocates say. They and 31 members of Congress are urging the US to grant undocumented Haitian immigrants like Delva what's known as temporary protected status, allowing them to stay and work in the US legally but temporarily.

On October 3, pushed by local activists, Haitian president Rene Preval made his first public request for TPS since the storms.

The move, they hope, will spur the US to grant the status. It's not unheard of.

Two weeks ago, the Bush administration announced it would extend temporary protected status to an estimated 300,000 Honduran, Nicaraguan and Salvadoran nationals who have been allowed to stay for years after natural disasters struck their countries.

It was granted to Hondurans and Nicaraguans after Hurricane Mitch hit in 1998 and to Salvadorans after a series of earthquakes in 2001.

While immigrant advocates argue it's unfair to deny Haiti the same benefit afforded those countries, opponents say the fact that the immigrants from those other places are still in the US is proof the system doesn't work.

"If Bush had ended the TPS for the Central American countries, then we would be in favour of TPS for Haitians," said Roy Beck, president of NumbersUSA, which advocates reduced immigration. "The reason we don't is that there's no 'T' in TPS."

David Abraham, a University of Miami law professor and immigration expert, said the country's mood toward immigration was much different 10 years ago. He doesn't think Preval's public statement will have an effect.

"This situation in Haiti has been so horrendous for so long that I don't see how additional misery would change the situation," he said.

Local activists estimate there are about 15,000 Haitians here with orders to leave.

"I just don't know how dire conditions have to become before the US government is willing to grant Haiti this long-merited assistance," said Representative Alcee Hastings, a Democrat from Florida.

The advocates argue deporting immigrants with no criminal record delivers Haitians a double blow: It cuts off income for their families here and abroad.

"When you deport someone to that country, all you're doing is adding another mouth to feed and cutting off support to Haiti," said Steven Forester, senior policy advocate at Haitian Women of Miami.

"If you want Haiti to get stable and get on its feet, you stop deportations so that we keep the money flowing there."

US Immigration and Customs Enforcement temporarily stopped deporting Haitians last month. But that's not the same as TPS. The pause could end at any moment, and it doesn't allow undocumented immigrants from Haiti to work legally.

Also, ICE agents continue to detain Haitians, even those like Delva - his American wife is five months pregnant. Married just three months when he was detained, he was picked up by ICE at his job before he filed his paperwork seeking residency.

"I respect the law. I love my family," Delva said from a detention centre. "Now I have a child on the way, and I'd like to be able to help my family."

For now, though, Delva waits in limbo, detained but not deported, with no resolution in sight.

Cannabis users face new penalties when the drug is upgraded to class B from January next year, the home secretary said today.

Jacqui Smith said that those caught with cannabis for a second time would be fined £80 and after three strikes would be arrested.

The drug was downgraded to class C in 2004, but fears over the increased use of stronger "skunk" strains among young people prompted a policy review and U-turn.

Smith said she was "extremely concerned" about skunk, and its impact on mental health, especially if young people started to use it at an early age or "binge smoke".

Skunk contains higher levels of THC, the active ingredient in cannabis.

"While cannabis has always been illegal, reclassifying it to a class B drug reinforces our message to everyone that it is harmful and should not be taken," she said.

"Fewer people are taking cannabis, but it is crucial that this trend continues. I am extremely concerned about the use of stronger strains of cannabis, such as skunk, and the harm they can cause to mental health.

Smith announced last May that she would go against the recommendations of the government's scientific experts, the Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs, which was asked by the home secretary to take its third look at cannabis classification in recent years.

The council's advice was that cannabis should remain class C.

Under current rules, anyone caught twice with cannabis can still walk away with a warning.

Smith said she had accepted police chiefs' calls for escalating penalties for possession in England and Wales.

Smith said: "This is the next step towards toughening up our enforcement response - to ensure that repeat offenders know that we are serious about tackling the danger that the drug poses to individuals and, in turn, communities.

"We need to act now to protect future generations."

Prosecutions and jail sentences for using and supplying cannabis plummeted after the then-home secretary David Blunkett downgraded cannabis in January 2004.

But police began to report that drugs seizures were much more likely to involve skunk than resin or lower strength marijuana.

Humberside chief constable Tim Hollis, who speaks on drugs for the Association of Chief Police Officers, promised a "harder line" on drug users.

"Where cannabis use is repeated or where there are aggravating circumstances locally, officers will take a harder line on enforcement and escalate their response accordingly.

"Every encounter at street level provides intelligence and helps us to act against the criminal gangs who seek to profit from cannabis production and distribution."

Danny Kushlick from the Transform Drug Policy Foundation condemned the move, accusing ministers of "populist posturing".

He said: "Escalating penalties for possession only serve to further marginalise and criminalise millions of otherwise law-abiding people.

"Criminalisation of cannabis possession is discriminatory and disproportionate when compared with tobacco and alcohol possession and counterproductive in so far as it gifts the market to organised criminals and drives the trade underground."

The process for changing the classification of the drug requires votes in both Houses of Parliament. If both votes pass, the new rules will come into force on January 26.

Chancellor Angela Merkel has announced a huge rescue package worth up to €500bn (£391bn) to inject movement into Germany's stricken banking and insurance sector.

The bail-out, endorsed by the cabinet at lunchtime, amounts to the biggest state intervention in the economy of Germany since the end of the second world war.

It includes €400bn in guarantees for interbank lending to restore liquidity and €100bn in fresh capital.

Merkel said: "The measures have one goal: they should ensure that there is confidence – between the banks, in the economy and amongst the citizens."

She said the state was "custodian of the law" and, as such, had to "be tough" to "ensure that that which we've experienced isn't repeated". She said the package came with new, tougher regulations for the financial sector.

Even before the endorsement of the bill, which is closely modelled on the British rescue plan unveiled last week, news of the proposal sent shares on the Frankfurt stock exchange soaring. The Dax index rose 6.53%.

The German bill, which will have to go before parliament for final approval later this week, will enable the finance ministry to issue credit guarantees for interbank lending worth €400bn up until the end of December 2009.

The ministry will also be empowered to withdraw about €100bn from the federal budget to back up guarantees and inject fresh capital into banks and insurance companies, which can decide whether they wish to participate in the scheme.

All institutions participating will be forced to give the finance ministry the power to make decisions on aspects of company policy and the way they use funds. Some experts have called the restrictions on participating institutions "punitive".

The bail-out package marks a change in direction by the German government, which had resisted taking stakes in the country's troubled banks.

Hypo Real Estate, the country's fourth biggest bank, assembled its own €50bn rescue package last week to guarantee credit lines.

But Berlin has been forced into a U-turn due to the shortage of liquidity held by German banks, resulting from the slump in markets and the difficulty in securing short-term lending.

The German government said the package had ruined its hopes of having a balanced budget by 2011 for the first time in years.

The process of rationalising our banks has begun. Royal Bank of Scotland and HBOS will be in effective state ownership very soon: I have little doubt that within a short period Lloyds TSB and Barclays will follow.

This nationalisation is essential: our economic system will collapse without it. But I stress: this has to be nationalisation, not support, for all the reasons Ken Livingstone and John McDonnell have argued. There is more than ideology in this though: outright nationalisation is needed if the government is to take control of this situation at a time when no one else can.

All this, however, raises two questions. The first concerns how to nationalise the banks. The second is what strategy those banks should be required to adopt once in state control.

On the first point the answer is relatively straightforward. No money must be wasted on buying out shareholders now. Every penny is needed to support the system. In that case the government should now take control of all banks requiring support by subscribing for new voting shares that give them majority control whilst designating the existing capital "B" shares that will have their value frozen at Friday's market price (unless it falls before the injection takes place). Those shareholders who will have their investment frozen will simply get interest on their capital at 3% in the short term – about equivalent to the rate of bank dividends.

The government must then take immediate action to underpin the value of the banks. First it must require the banks to lend to each other. Since they will be owned in common they can now take risk on lending within the UK. There should also be full openness with the banks to be nationalised in other states. We're not in competition now. This openness would massively reduce the risk of interbank lending. The system could start again.

Next we will require full bank cooperation in the creation of a social housing corporation to take control of properties on which there are failing mortgages. It's not just banks that need bailing out: people do to. I created a plan to do this in July this year before the need became as pressing as it now is. This will restore essential stability in one market. This is more important than toxic debt in the short term: real people with real lives need to know they will have roofs over their heads.

After that, the banks have to re-order their priorities. Those activities that undermine the state, whether they be tax haven operations, private wealth management divisions or structured finance arms that engage solely in abusive tax planning to deny governments the cash that is now being used to bail them out, must be shut. The political signal must be sent that the world has changed and the bank model that was designed to undermine the state (as it was) is now history.

Then the nationalised banks will have to appraise which of their activities are profitable and can still carry on without support. Insurance brokerages, domestic asset leasing companies, and even branch banking may all be profitable in their own right. If so these need to be refloated on the stock market as soon as possible for three reasons. First they do not need sorting out; second we need to restore faith in those markets and third we can use their reflotation values to effectively pay for the shares in the banks that will have been frozen on nationalisation. Shares in these new companies will be subscribed for by cancelling the value of the existing shares in issue. If done properly I have little doubt not a penny will need to be paid to existing shareholders as value is realised. I will go so far as to suggest sufficient value should be realisable to allow for the creation of new mutual organisations: the return of Halifax to the high street as a mutual does, for example, could bolster this vital part of the savings sector.

And then the government will be left with the toxic problems including the derivatives, the more problematic banking arrangements, the hedge fund stakes, the investment banking and trading divisions that have underpinned the failure, and more. That is appropriate. First, because these are the assets that will require state support whilst the solvency issues they create are resolved.

Second, because by the time this rump is left there will have been sufficient asset sales or reflotations for confidence to have been built in the policy of the government managing bank risk, meaning that confidence will have been established in their ability to solve these problems too.

Third, it is in these areas of activity that radical reform of banking practices is required if further toxic activity is to be avoided, and a significant period of public ownership may be required before sufficient re-education and reformulation of banking regulation can take place to ensure that this process can be successfully undertaken. This will require, for example, a radical review of the future of the whole of western banking's approach to speculative trading, the use of hedge funds, derivatives, offshore, securitisation and many related issues such as the reporting of corporate risk, its auditing, means of incentivising those who work in banks and more. The right of a bank to even create money, as they have done without control for the last few decades, might even be questioned. The role of the mutual sector and of pensions will also need to be considered: they are integral to the long-term role of the financial sector as a whole. I do not pretend that any of these issues can be addressed in the short term and as such some time must elapse before it will be either safe or even possible to return some reformed establishments willing to engage in risk-based banking activity to the private sector once more.
But what is absolutely clear is that unless those who are now appointed to take control of the banks have a strategy such as this in mind, all we will be doing is giving enormous sums of money to bankers to lose, and if there is one option that is politically unacceptable, this is it. And that's why the almost total absence of comment about what we will do once the banks have been nationalised is for me one of the most worrying features of this last weekend.

The counter-terrorism bill returns to parliament this afternoon.

Click back from 3.10pm for minute-by-minute coverage.

2:53pm: It's all go in Westminster today. As the government grapples with the financial crisis, controversial legislation which aims to increase the limit terror suspects can be detained without charge from 28 days to 42 returns to parliament this afternoon almost unnoticed.

3:12pm: Peers are expected to inflict an embarrassing defeat on the government when the counter-terrorism bill is debated at committee stage in the House of Lords. Rumour has it that the government could lose by more than 100 votes.

Former shadow home secretary David Davis – who resigned as an MP to highlight the threat to civil liberties posed by the bill – yesterday described the legislation as "dead".

Of course, if peers do strike out the proposal, the government still has the option of using the Parliament Act to force it on to the statute books, but the prime minister has already signalled his reluctance to do so – why court more controversy and subject your government to another tumultuous time in the Commons when you can quietly drop the proposal and retain the less controversial aspects of the bill?

3:23pm: The debate is expected to start at about 3.10pm and the vote on the 42-day aspect of the bill will be – depending on how many peers want to speak – some time after 5pm.

They're off. Lord Dear, a crossbencher, outlines why he has set down an amendment to the proposed legislation.

"The government now suggests that the 28-day limit is too restrictive," he said. "They say it needs to be increased for 42-days in some circumstances." But Dear argues that no other country like ours has extended detention without charge to 28 days, let alone 42 days.

"In Canada it is only one day," Dear says. "How is it that they can manage but we can't?"

3:25pm: George Foulkes, a former Labour minister and government loyalist, intervenes to ask how this tallies with Guantanamo Bay. Dear politely bats away the question.

3:33pm: The existing law is sufficient, he says, with only a slight change – for police to charge a terror suspect with a lesser offence. They could then up the offence when more evidence became available.

"I believe we have gone far enough [with the existing law]," Dear says. The attempt to appear tough on terrorism is a "shabby charade and we should reject it".

3:36pm: Next up is Lady Neville-Jones, the former chairman of the joint intelligence committee and shadow security minister, who describes the legislation on 42-days as "unnecessary, undesirable and unworkable".

3:42pm: The safeguards the government has put in place not only make the legislation unworkable, they are also undesirable, she says.

3:45pm: Lord Thomas of Gresford, the Liberal Democrat legal affairs spokesman, reminds peers of the difficulties air passengers have faced because of the restrictions on carrying liquids.

He goes on to list a string of trials for airline plots. "Only three of those 24 or 25 cases resulted in a conviction and those were unrelated to the airline plot," he says. "Would the outcome have been any different if they had been held for 42 days? There is no case whatsoever for suggesting 42 days will bring about a conviction when 28 days will not."

3:58pm: Lady Mallalieu, a Labour peer, says it is not a "comfortable or happy position to find myself voting against my own party". But she says she cannot support 42 days.

4:02pm: Foulkes interjects again to ask what is the difference in principle between 28 days and 42 days? Mallalieu says there is a difference and she will come to it shortly.

"These provisions are an own-goal," she says. Arguing that the government's proposed safeguards will have "as much substance as the back of the envelope they were drawn up on", she insists it will be impossible to ensure effective judicial or parliamentary oversight.

4:04pm: Mallalieu wonders what all the peers are doing there debating the issue. "I wonder if it is for some political gain. I hope not," she says.

"Our freedoms are under threat here and for no good reason. It's time to say stop."

4:12pm: Lord Carlile of Berriew, a Lib Dem peer, says he will not vote on the legislation because of his interest in it – he carried out an independent review of British anti-terrorist laws – but he says he fears some of the arguments he has heard, prior to today, are "disqualified from serious debate".

He lists some of arguments against the bill – breaching civil liberties, proposing internment, etc, and dismisses them one by one. And he accuses Lord Dear of "misrepresenting the situation".

4:18pm: Carlile then goes on to list five main reasons for supporting the bill, including the increased risk of violent terrorism, the safety of our children and the need to stay one step ahead of terrorist networks that continually regenerate themselves.

4:20pm: Carlile says he is concerned with "the enduring integrity of the law".

"The one thing I dread is some huge event, where a plane or something is driven into a crowd, leading to thousands of deaths," he tells peers. "I want to see an end to the constant introduction of new terrorism law. I want a counter-terror law that we can consolidate and that will endure."

4:23pm: Viscount Bledisloe, a crossbench peer, interrupts to say: "The noble Lord talks about finality and consolidation, is he really saying 42 days will solve all the problems for all time?"

Carlile retorts: "No, any more than the Magna Carta was available for all time, but it will do for now."

4:30pm: Lord Elton, a Conservative peer, interjects to point out that Carlile has not answered the point that under the existing law it is possible to continue looking for evidence right up until the trial.

Carlile says he has answered that point and ends his contribution by urging peers to back the legislation.

"It's what I think, it's what I believe and it's what I advise," he says.

4:34pm: The Earl of Onslow, another Conservative peer, argues that there is no need for the legislation because there is no increase in threat.

Foulkes jumps to his feet again, claiming Onslow is "manifestly wrong" and adds: "As are all his other remarks."

4:38pm: Onslow sticks to his guns, prompting another interruption, this time from Lord Wedderburn of Charlton, who asks what evidence of a threat Onslow needs… "A manifesto from Osama bin Laden?"

Onslow says he has asked for evidence but has not received any. "I hope you will reject this ill-thought-out proposal," he adds.

4:40pm: Lord Falconer of Thoroton, the former Lord Chancellor, then stands up and says the idea that extending the limit to 42 days would lead to more convictions was "utterly fanciful".

"If I thought extending the number of days would assist in bringing terrorists to justice then I would support it, but I do not accept it," he says.

4:43pm: Falconer says he agrees with Carlile about the threat level. "There is a substantial threat to the whole community," he says, but extending the limit to 42 days would not help.

"That is why, with a heavy heart, I will vote against it," he says.

4:56pm: Lord Lloyd of Berwick, a crossbencher, reminds peers that the law remains 14 days and not 28 days – currently special permission from a court is required to extend detention without charge to 28 days.

Wedderburn is up again. He says that in this complex world, police sometimes need longer to gather evidence.

4:58pm: The Conservative peer, Lord Tebbit, stands to explain why he will support the government this evening.

He questions how Falconer could support 90 days "while in office" but not 42 days now. "We have to take account of the fact that things are changing," he says. "Victims have human rights just as much as suspects… The weight in the scales is disproportionate.

"Think of the dilemma if the government is denied these powers tonight, but at some time in the future a Conservative government decides that it needs them. My party might come to rue this day if they win the vote. Part of my reason for supporting the government is to protect my party at some time in the future," he says.

5:02pm: According to the Press Association, David Davis, the former shadow home secretary who resigned from the Commons and fought a byelection in protest to the bill, is watching the debate from the steps of the throne, inside the chamber.

5:20pm: I should point out that it's not possible to live blog from the upper house, so I'm watching it on the BBC Parliament channel.

5:22pm: Lord Imbert, a crossbencher, says: "Although I've heard much genuine concern about the human rights of suspects, I've not heard enough about the human rights of victims or potential victims."

He says he does not accept that to request an extension, sometimes of just a few hours beyond 28 days, would be "a recruiting sergeant for al-Qaeda".

"There must be provision for a properly supervised extension to 28 days," he says.

5:28pm: Lord Howarth of Newport, a Labour peer who used to sit on the parliamentary intelligence and security committee, sets out the realities of terrorism in today's world.

"The defence of the realm and safety of our citizens is the primary duty that a government has," he says.

Lady Warsi, a Conservative peer, interjects to ask whether it is not more important that a majority of people feel "part of big-tent Britain". That would be a better long-term solution to terrorism, she suggests.

Lord Howard says he does not want to give parliament "excessive powers" to erode civil liberties, but he does not think the government is overreacting in this case. The bill contains powerful safeguards and the amendment to the bill is "ill-conceived", he says.

6:00pm: Baroness Ramsay of Cartvale, a Labour peer and former MI6 spy, said a maximum of 28 days was "inadequate for the threat we now face". She said people who were "currently, directly involved in counter-terrorism all say we need more than 28 days".

"As such it [the government's legislation] deserves our support," she said.

6:06pm: Lord West of Spithead, the home office minister, is now responding for the government. He says the government would not be asking for these measures if it didn't think they were needed.

"All of us would prefer to be in a position where a charge could be brought within 48 hours," he said. "But unfortunately we are not in that position."

If the police waited to act it could lead to scores or even hundreds or thousands of casualties, he says.

6:19pm: West, a former head of the British Navy and one of the "Goats" brought into government by Gordon Brown under his Government of All the Talents initiative, reads his pre-written speech perfectly competently, but it doesn't sound like one of those "from the heart" addresses likely to sway the undecideds.

Peers who periodically left the chamber during the debate have returned in anticipation of the vote ...

6:38pm: Dear gets a final go at persuading people to back his amendent 29, which would prevent the home secretary extending pre-charge detention beyond 28 days.

And finally, they vote on amendment 29 - result soon ...

6:52pm: The government is defeated by 118 to 309, majority 191.

Today at 5.30pm, environmental activists, in Edwardian costume, will throng Parliament Square – and we are all invited to join them, dressed as we are. Taking inspiration from the suffragettes' "parliament rush" of 1908, the Climate Rush, a legal demonstration in which some MPs will participate, seeks to press the urgency of climate change, at a time when it seems to take second place in government policy to short-term economic calculations.

For while Gordon Brown in 2007 staked Britain's claim to world leadership on climate change, describing it as "the great project of this generation", his government's actions are less impressive. While the climate change bill moves slowly through parliament, we have last Thursday's decision for the extension of Stansted airport after lobbying from BAA, approval for new runways at Heathrow and City airports, and hinted plans to build a new generation of coal-fired electricity plants. At the same time, the British government has made no response to either the offer by Guyana (where I was born) of trusteeship over 40m acres of virgin rain forest in exchange for modest development assistance or Ecuador's request for help so it can afford not to allow oil extraction in its corner of the Amazon.

The irony of the proposed new coal-fired power station in Kent is that it lies in a region which will be invaded by the ocean if sea levels rise as high as feared. Few serious scientists have any doubt that burning coal and oil over three centuries drove rises in carbon dioxide levels, and with it climate change, and that we are at the brink of catastrophic change. At the poles, in the Maldives, on the coasts of England itself, the evidence is before our eyes. And the British public is aware of this: Defra's 2007 survey showed public opinion viewed the environment as among the five most urgent matters – above taxes, immigration, and pensions.

But public opinion has long come last in state decisions – and this why the Climate Rush has chosen to wear the red suffragette sash. One hundred years on, we may all have the vote, but almost all are still among the politically excluded. The climate activists are mainly people in their 20s who marched against an attack on Iraq in 2002 and 2003, and were ignored by the majority in parliament. They have seen, most recently at the Climate Camp in August, how the "anti-terrorism" and "serious crime" legislation passed in haste in 2000 and 2005 have been used against peaceful protest, and to distance parliament from the people. We should all share their impatience that this government, elected only by scarcely more than one-fifth of the eligible population, answer to the public on climate change.

The tragedy of the Labour governments of 1997-2008 is that they kept the old Fabian arrogance about governing on behalf of the people, while having lost the confidence of the Webbs and Shaws, and the heroic generation of 1945, that public interest should prevail over private. For whether it is stopping the prosecution of corruption "on the grounds of national security" on behalf of the arms industry, linking aid to Africa to the privatisation of utilities to the benefit of water companies, or overruling planners to allow airport expansion on behalf of the aviation lobby, New Labour rarely finds a principle which it won't bend on behalf of a British corporation. In part this is because of their supine posture towards the tarnished marketist idols of the 1980s. But it is also our fault: while corporations press their interests, most citizens accept elections every few years as a substitute for democracy. Our passivity in front of parliament has made this possible.

The Climate Rush is at once an explicit call for Britain to meet its promise to lead the global fight against climate change, and an implicit demand for the renewal of British democracy, for a parliament closer to the people. It might even be seen as in invitation for the Labour party to return to its Edwardian roots. The suffragettes, of course, were kept waiting so long for their bill by the Liberals that they ended up in the hands of the Tories: will that happen with environmentalists? See you in Westminster.

Today's big story is The Reboot. "Fire the campaign," urges Bill Kristol in his New York Times column (itself probably a trial balloon floated before the politico-journalistic world to gauge reaction). Nothing they're doing is working. Kristol urges the following seven steps:

1. Run as accessible "happy warriors," providing completely media access to both candidates, just as McCain 1.0 used to do.

2. Do local radio, talk shows, town halls, anything – and invite Obama and Biden to join them.

3. Drop the attacks, period and end of story. They aren't working.

4. Stop unveiling gimmicky proposals designed to win that day's spin war (you know – the kind Bill Kristol was wild about a few weeks ago!).

5. Make "the substantive case for his broadly centrist conservatism."

6. Remind voters that the Democrats are going to be in charge of Congress, and that Democratic control of both branches will result in a return to 1970s-style unchecked taxing and spending.

7. Offer "a mild mea culpa" at Wednesday's debate about the nasty turn this race has taken.

Well, that's five short of what alcoholics are supposed to do, but I suppose Kristol doesn't think McCain is quite that far gone.

Meanwhile, Mike Allen reports at Politico today that McCain has retooled his stump speech. The campaign provided Allen an excerpt:

"The national media has written us off. Senator Obama is measuring the drapes, and planning with Speaker Pelosi and Senator Reid to raise taxes, increase spending, take away your right to vote by secret ballot in labor elections, and concede defeat in Iraq. But they forgot to let you decide. My friends, we've got them just where we want them."

Don't scoff. This isn't over. It's heading in the direction of being over, yes. But it's not over. Obama's leads are small enough in about six swing states that his victories there are by no means a lock. Those states are worth around 80 electoral votes, and a swing of 80 electoral votes could well mean a narrow McCain victory. That means that something big has to happen that changes the direction of the momentum in all six of those states, which would certainly be unusual. But it isn't impossible.

So what do you do? You change direction and try to give yourself a fresh start. You talk about the other guy "measuring the drapes" already – a tried and true tactic. And you do some of the things Kristol suggests.

I think Item 6 is potentially the most effective on Kristol's list. Lots of history suggests that Americans like divided government – they like a congressional check led by party B on a president of party A. Circumstances in which they happily give both the executive and legislative branches to one party are comparatively rare. Even during the "Reagan revolution," Ronald Reagan never had a GOP Congress (Senate yes, for a time, but never the House). Bill Clinton had a Democratic Congress for two years, and then voters turned Congress Republican.

So that line could work. As could others among Kristol's proposals. But I feel like there's still something missing here.

Jackie Calmes of the New York Times reported it first – that, after a tense meeting between the candidate and top aides yesterday at which they were supposed to agree on some new economic proposals he would roll out this week, they emerged empty-handed. Calmes reports that the principals couldn't reach consensus on anything:

The signs of internal confusion came as the campaign was under pressure from state party leaders to sharpen his message on the economy and at least blunt the advantage that Democrats traditionally have on the issue in hard times…

… Mr. McCain's policy adviser, Douglas Holtz-Eakin, said, "I have no comment on anything, to anybody."

That doesn't sound like a happy fellow.

So here, once again, we have what seems to me the same situation that has plagued his campaign since the summer. Appearance before substance. It's fine to retool speeches and promise that you're still in the fight. It's fine to open the curtain between the press section of the plane and the candidate's berth. It's fine to do all these things. And they may help.

But if one were forced to name one reason why McCain is losing, it's that he's responded poorly, from a substantive point of view, to the current economic crisis. He put appearance before substance then, too. As I've written many times, and I'll say it again because it just gets truer and truer with every passing week: McCain built a campaign that was designed to win the wars of the daily news cycles, not the long-term battle.

So Kristol's suggestions are fine, really. But notice that only one, Item 5, is fully about substance.

The media will help push the reboot story line. It's superficial but it's a fact of life – the reporters want a race, and they'll gobble up a story line about "McCain's new momentum" if they think it'll help get their stories on page one. So McCain will benefit from that. The gap will close a little. But if McCain doesn't have stronger and more compelling things to say about the economy, the cosmetics can't save him.

Today in the House of Lords I shall vote against the government's proposal to increase the maximum period of pre-charge detention to 42 days, for exactly the same reasons that I voted against its previous proposal to increase it to 90 days. Since that vote my views have been strengthened, for reasons that I will explain.

In 1974, I commanded my regiment on the streets of West Belfast, when internment without trial was still in existence. All internal security operations depend on intelligence, not least low-level or what is called human intelligence that results from contact with ordinary citizens. Because of internment, this was almost impossible to obtain, and we operated in an atmosphere that was hostile both to us and what we were there to do.

In 1978, I returned to Belfast to command the brigade there, by which time internment had been lifted. The contrast in atmosphere and relationships with ordinary citizens could not have been greater. There was far greater understanding of what we were there to do, and it was possible to hold meetings with local people who mattered in some degree of normality. True, women banged dustbin lids on the pavements on the night of August 9, to remind everyone that that was the date when internment was introduced in 1971, but progress was possible without that impediment.

To me, 42 days represents internment without trial and, having experienced the difficulties it causes to the forces of law and order, in internal security operations, I could not vote to impose similar difficulties on those who have that role on our streets today.

I am sure that many people will have read The Islamist by Ed Husain, which describes very vividly how difficult life is for young Muslims in Britain today. The proposed legislation has its roots in acts of terrorism perpetrated by young Muslims, resulting in an increasingly hostile public attitude towards them.

Earlier in the year, I attended a lecture entitled Deflating Global Islamism by Maajid Nawaz, a long-time friend and university colleague of Ed Husain who, like him, had been recruited by Hizb ut-Tahrir, (the Liberation party) an extremist Islamist organisation. He had become a national speaker and international recruiter, exporting its ideology to Pakistan and then Denmark. In 2002, immediately after 9/11, he was arrested in Egypt and sentenced to five years' imprisonment for belonging to the organisation.

On release, he and Husain resigned from Hizb ut-Tahrir and began to write and give lectures on their ideological objections to Islamism in general and the organisation in particular, launching the Quilliam Foundation to further that work. After his lecture, I asked Nawaz about the impact of the 42-day proposal on young, impressionable Muslims and on organisations like Hizb ut-Tahrir. "It's the best recruiting sergeant they could get," was his reply.

So why, when it is essential to do all that we can to integrate all those who successfully apply for British citizenship into our society, should we deliberately take an unnecessary step that is likely to cause, rather than solve, the very difficulties we are trying to avoid? I am delighted that current experts such as Lady Manningham-Buller, Lord Dear and, most recently, the former assistant commissioner Andy Hayman, have commented that the proposals in the bill, especially the 42-day extension, are not fit for purpose. It is absolutely true. I can only suppose that those responsible for the proposal have not thought through the practical implications for those whose job it is to maintain law and order, or for members of the public with whom, to keep that order, they must maintain good relationships.

To walk into Dominique Gonzalez-Foerster's new installation at Tate Modern is like walking into a sci-fi movie - a deeply disturbing, rather dark experience in which you the viewer project your own narrative and your own anxieties on to the piece. And, I suspect, with TH.2058 (as it is called), Tate has another Turbine Hall hit on its hands. Not only does it have at its heart the kind of "interactivity" that is so popular among visitors to Tate Modern, but also, with its apocalyptic vision, it seems deeply in tune with the times.

At the bottom of the ramp your path is blocked by heavy red and green plastic curtains and the insistent sound of rain. You are about to be transported 50 years into the future, you are told. Push the plastic barriers aside and you are in some kind of bunk-bed-filled disaster shelter - somewhere between Henry Moore's drawings of communal air-raid shelters in the blitz and the nightmarish dormitories of Soylent Green or Blindness, or of certain scenes in Battlestar Galactica.

On the bunks sit books - things like Fahrenheit 451 and The War of the Worlds - which distance you from the disaster-bunker fiction, but might also give you the chance for a peaceful 45 minutes on your back doing some background reading. Most grippingly, enormous sculptures soar above you. They look oddly familiar - isn't that Louise Bourgeois's Maman, the huge steel spider that's in the Tate's collection? Only ... it's much bigger than you remember it, and when you walk up to it and feel its cold surface, you suddenly realise you are feeling warm painted polystyrene. There's a vast Alexander Calder here too - his soaring red Flamingo - again bigger than real life. And an oversize Bruce Nauman, and a giant Henry Moore. It is as if they have grown (the insistent rain has fed these strange animals, perhaps, or we have diminished). It seems no coincidence that some of the sculptors here have been responsible for previous Turbine Hall installations. On a giant screen at the front of all this is a montage of sci-fi movies: clips from Solaris, Repulsion, Zabriskie Point and more. The Last Film, it's called. As if when the world ends we'll be watching it going down in fiction.

We're at the point where we're obsessed with the visible manifestations of the campaign right now – the stump speeches, the ads, whether the Bill Ayers attacks are working. But let's step back and consider something that isn't immediately visible, something that might have a big impact on how this race winds down. In a word, money.

Two questions you may not have thought about in the past week: How much money is Obama probably raising right now, and how much are the Republicans raising?

Obama will announce his September totals next week. He raised a record $66m in August. Doesn't it seem safe to say that the September number will be north of that? Maybe $75m? And what about the October figure? He could hit $100m in a single month. Even if that proves high, the guesstimate of another $75m or so, a more conservative projection today, would have seemed mind-blowing a few months ago.

You could tell last week that Obama was swimming in cash when his campaign announced that it had purchased 30-minute blocs of air time during prime time on three different networks. Every indication is that he could practically buy the whole week on a network if he wanted to, but the big shows are starting their new seasons. As much enthusiasm as he's generated, he's still probably no match for Grey's Anatomy.

Meanwhile, on the GOP side…McCain, remember, accepted public financing for the general election, which Obama did not, so McCain gets his money from the federal government. He and his party can, however, raise money that goes technically not to him but to the party. It can't be spent on campaign travel and payroll, but it can be spent on television advertising, mailings and other activities that support the presidential ticket.

I should think they had a strong September – remember, McCain was ahead for the first half of September, until the financial crisis hit. But how must they be doing now? In all likelihood, not nearly as well.

McCain's campaign is now at the point – seven, eight points behind with just three weeks remaining; also, unsure of its message and direction – where the political pros in the party start making choices. They look at the amount of money the party is bringing in. They look at the state of McCain's campaign and start making sober calculations about the chance of his winning.

Then, they size up the races for Senate and the House of Representatives. They start telling themselves things like, "Well, okay, maybe we lose the presidency. But we've got to keep the Democrats from getting 60 senators. We've got to try to hold on in North Carolina, Minnesota and Oregon." And as far as the House of Representatives goes, momentum is still moving in the Democrats' direction. They may pick up 12 seats, which would give them a hefty 61-seat advantage.

Republican operatives want desperately to recapture control of that body. And they know very well that every 10 or so seats you're behind there adds another two or four years to the project. So they have a very strong interest in trying to keep losses there to a minimum.

So, with fewer resources at their disposal than the Obama campaign, the Republicans are going to have to start making choices. My hunch is that McCain has a week to show that he can break through in Virginia, Ohio, North Carolina and Florida (65 electoral votes all told). He's slightly behind in Ohio, North Carolina and Florida, and somewhat more than slightly behind in Virginia.

If McCain can show by next weekend that he's nudged the needle in these states in his direction, his campaign managers will probably be able to persuade the party's money people to keep the infusions coming.

But if he can't, history shows that they'll start cutting their losses and moving their spending to the protection of congressional incumbents. As you read blind quotes from GOP operatives over the next few days, keep an eye out for hints of this.
